caption_original:
Atlantic Canada is currently seeing an outbreak of Trichomonosis. It is a bird parasite that affects the upper digestive tract of birds, limiting their ability to swallow and keep their food down. 

Although bird feeders and baths make it easier for us to watch birds in their natural habitat, they can be harmful during an outbreak. You can help slow down the spread of Trichomonosis by removing bird feeders and baths and following  these simple steps: 

BIRD FEEDERS AND BATHS
1) Take down your bird feeders and bird baths. During the summer, there is enough natural food available, so there is no need to worry. 
2) Wash them thoroughly with a weak bleach solution (5% sodium hypochlorite).
3) Dispose of any wet or exposed feed left around your bird feeders and baths.
4) Refrain from putting them back in your yard until the cooler temperatures in the Fall.

For more information on Trichomonosis: http://ow.ly/Qr7y30dZhU9

caption_original:
With a watershed that spans four provinces and four states, Lake Winnipeg is Canada‚Äôs sixth largest lake and an important resource for Canadians. Lake Winnipeg is also culturally, socially and economically significant to the health of Indigenous peoples and their communities. 

It is also important to the Canadian economy, generating millions of dollars of revenue in the hydroelectric, recreation and commercial freshwater fishing industries. That‚Äôs why the Government of Canada is investing $25.7 million for the Lake Winnipeg Basin Program. The Program will include efforts to reduce nutrients and improve water quality, and engaging Indigenous partners and collaborators at all levels in Canada and U.S. for strong action to protect shared waters of Lake Winnipeg. http://ow.ly/mKXY30dRTPv
caption_cleaned: With a watershed that spans four provinces and four states, Lake Winnipeg is Canada‚Äôs sixth largest lake and an important resource for Canadians. Lake Winnipeg is also culturally, socially and economically significant to the health of Indigenous peoples and their communities. It is also important to the Canadian economy, generating millions of dollars of revenue in the hydroelectric, recreation and commercial freshwater fishing industries. That‚Äôs why the Government of Canada is investing $25.7 million for the Lake Winnipeg Basin Program. The Program will include efforts to reduce nutrients and improve water quality, and engaging Indigenous partners and collaborators at all levels in Canada and U.S. for strong action to protect shared waters of Lake Winnipeg.

On March 4, 1960, at 1:06 a.m. local time, a meteor flashed through the sky near Bruderheim, Alberta. The sound of its impact hitting Earth was audible over 5,000 square kilometres. Weighing in at over 300 kilograms, the Bruderheim Meteorite still holds the title of Canada‚Äôs largest discovered meteorite. And at roughly 4.6 billion years old, it‚Äôs fair to say it‚Äôs a gem in our National Meteorite Collection. #InternationalRockDay!
http://ow.ly/mZ5A30dC3fK

caption_original:
Ammonites are fossils of an unusual marine cephalopod invertebrates that went extinct about 65 million years ago. Due to their distinct characteristics, paleontologists from around the world study, classify and use them as indicators of geological time periods.

Today, different species have been found around the Pacific Rim, in Japan, Russia, Alaska, British Columbia and California. Their relatives ‚Äî squid, octopus and nautilus ‚Äî still live in today‚Äôs oceans.
http://ow.ly/waJA30dzCeQ

Their relatives ‚Äî squid, octopus and nautilus ‚Äî still live in today‚Äôs oceans.
